label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, August 1, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing what he now looks like and trying to dissuade Gertrude of her ideals on how he looks. Sidney continues in his letter to discuss the war and Gertrude’s trip to their friend Polly’s.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing what he now looks like and trying to dissuade Gertrude of her ideals on how he looks. Sidney continues in his letter to discuss the war and Gertrude’s trip to their friend Polly’s.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
29
August 1, 1943
Dear Gertie,
I have just put down the phone and am still
smiling. It was such fun talking to you, and you have not
changed a bit. I had imagined after leaving Washington you
would just lie on the beach at Watch Hill and rest and sleep
for ever. Instead I find you back in your old stamping
grounds on the island full of vim and vigor.
Unfortunately I do not appe r to be able to
clear up a misunderstanding on your part that I am a sun bunred
greek God comming ashore on a sr_fboard strumming a guitar
in one hand while I use the other ot give emphasis to the
wide variety of hula steps that I am cognizant of. I am so
afraid that you have let your immagination run away with you
that when you see me again it will be quite a shock to
find what I re[a]lly look like, and learn that I cannot do all
the wonderful things that you now give me credit for.
I am the same man who use to have indegestion after meals,
is so sleepy by nine oclock that he has to go to bed, does not
want to go out to dinner and shuts his ears when people talk
informational interesting talk. I am tall and skinny except
that I now have quite a little pot and an enormous derriere.
This is the"me" you are going to see again so for goodness
sade don't start as picturing me as a movie hero because you
will never survive the shock.
Your trip is certainly cockeyed but do not worry
you will get off after a while. Transportation is that way.
They keep you waiting in the port for weeks some time and then
suddenly you are told to be a board in half an hour. However
according to you the war is almost over and there is very little
left but the shouting. Maybe the shouting will be the worst part.
The point I was trying to bring out was that maybe the war is
over in Europe, you should know more about that than I do ,
but the war is not even beggining in the Pacific. Do you realize
we are still fooling around the Solomon Islands, if you think 
that means a quick victory we have no meeting of minds on that 
subject. Also common sense will tell you that when the papers
report ten jap ships sunk some American ships must have gone down
in the battle. I of course hope it will be over soon and am
very much encouraged by what you have to say about it.
Pollys house sounds wonderful and that enourmous
room must have been heaven to sleep in , especially after the
heat of Washington. How in the world does she have servants.
I thought they did not exist any longer, a vanished race of
people. Out here they are now unknown, I believe there is
one stuffed one in the museum that people stare and g ape at, but
[End Page 1]
there are no live ones.
Morris just came back from the movies and said
they were terrible. He wanted to know all the news and
what you had to say, and asked if I had r emembered to gi e you
his love, which I had failed to do, so I send it to you
now.
Goodbye darling,
Sidney J. Legendre
[End Page 2]
